newsitem.title: INDIA: India defers decision on fresh wheat imports.
newsitem.headline: India defers decision on fresh wheat imports.

text.p: Indian government ministers on Saturday did not discuss the issue of fresh wheat imports in addition to the earlier authorised two million tonnes, Food Minister Devendra Prasad Yadav said.
"It was not discussed," Yadav told Reuters after the cabinet meeting. He did not give reasons.
Yadav had said earlier on Saturday the cabinet would discuss the issue at its meeting later in the day.
U.S. grain export sources said on Wednesday that India has contracted to import a fresh one million tonnes of wheat from Australia for August, November and December shipments.
"There is no plan to import (the fresh one million tonnes of wheat) yet," the Times of India newspaper quoted Agriculture Minister Chaturanan Mishra as saying.
In December, India asked state-run State Trading Corporation (STC) to import two million tonnes of wheat in fiscal 1996/97 (April-March) to build stocks and check rising prices.
The STC has so far contracted to import 1.7 million tonnes of wheat from the two million tonnes authorised, mainly from Australia, Canada and Argentina, company officials said.
In addition the STC earlier this month tendered to import 50,000 tonnes of wheat for arrivals from September onwards.
